myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't exercise during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Moderate exercise is generally safe and beneficial during pregnancy unless contraindicated by your doctor.
myths_vs_reality.source: ACOG (American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists)

myths_vs_reality.myth: ADHD is caused by bad parenting.
myths_vs_reality.reality: ADHD is a neurodevelopmental disorder with strong genetic components, not caused by parenting style.
myths_vs_reality.source: CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexia is just seeing letters backwards.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia is a language processing disorder affecting reading, writing, and spelling in various ways, not just letter reversal.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents of children with learning disorders should always put their child's needs before their own.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Parental self-care is essential; neglecting mental health harms both parent and child's wellbeing.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You're eating for two during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Most women only need about 300 extra calories per day in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters.

myths_vs_reality.myth: ADHD medications will turn children into zombies.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Properly prescribed and monitored medications help regulate brain chemistry without personality changes.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexic children are less intelligent.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia is unrelated to intelligence; many dyslexics have average or above-average IQ.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only mothers experience mental health challenges with special needs children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Fathers experience similar stress levels but may express it differently or seek help less often.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Morning sickness only happens in the morning.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Nausea can occur at any time of day and varies greatly among pregnant women.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Children with ADHD will outgrow it.
myths_vs_reality.reality: About 60% of children with ADHD continue to have symptoms into adulthood.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexia can be cured with more reading practice.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia is lifelong, but proper interventions can significantly improve reading skills.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents should feel guilty if they need respite care for their special needs child.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Respite care is a healthy way to prevent burnout and maintain family wellbeing.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can predict the baby's gender based on belly shape.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Belly shape is determined by muscle tone, baby's position, and body type, not gender.

myths_vs_reality.myth: ADHD is overdiagnosed.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While awareness has increased, many children (especially girls and minorities) remain undiagnosed.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexia is rare.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia affects about 15-20% of the population to varying degrees.
myths_vs_reality.source: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

myths_vs_reality.myth: Therapy is only for parents who can't cope.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Therapy is a proactive tool for all parents of children with learning differences.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Heartburn means your baby will have lots of hair.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Heartburn is caused by hormonal changes and physical pressure, not fetal hair.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Sugar causes ADHD.
myths_vs_reality.reality: No scientific evidence links sugar to ADHD, though diet may affect symptoms.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of the American Medical Association

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics can't be good at spelling if they try harder.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia affects phonological processing; effort alone doesn't overcome this neurological difference.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents should never show frustration in front of their special needs child.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Appropriate expression of emotions models healthy coping when done constructively.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Flying during pregnancy will cause a miscarriage.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Air travel is generally safe until 36 weeks for uncomplicated pregnancies; cosmic radiation exposure is minimal.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Having sex can hurt the baby.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Intercourse is safe in normal pregnancies; the fetus is well-protected by amniotic fluid and the uterus.
myths_vs_reality.source: Mayo Clinic Guide to a Healthy Pregnancy

myths_vs_reality.myth: All medications are dangerous during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many medications are pregnancy-safe; untreated conditions often pose greater risks than properly managed treatments.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Morning sickness means your pregnancy is healthier.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While nausea is common, its absence doesn't indicate problems; 20-30% of healthy pregnancies have no nausea.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You shouldn't lift your arms above your head or the umbilical cord will wrap around the baby's neck.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Arm movements don't affect the umbilical cord; nuchal cords occur randomly in 20-30% of pregnancies.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Hot tubs are completely off-limits.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Brief warm (not hot) soaks (<100°F for <10 mins) are generally safe after first trimester.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Bed rest prevents preterm labor.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Bed rest isn't proven effective and may increase risks of blood clots and muscle loss.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't get pregnant while breastfeeding.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Lactational amenorrhea method only works under strict conditions (≤6mo postpartum, exclusive feeding, no period return).

myths_vs_reality.myth: Caffeine causes birth defects.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Moderate caffeine (<200mg/day) isn't linked to defects but high intake may increase miscarriage risk.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All fish should be avoided due to mercury.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Low-mercury fish (salmon, shrimp) provide essential omega-3s; only high-mercury fish (swordfish, tilefish) should be avoided.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Bleeding always means miscarriage.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Light spotting occurs in 20% of healthy pregnancies; always report bleeding but don't assume the worst.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't dye your hair while pregnant.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Modern hair dyes have minimal systemic absorption; ensure good ventilation and avoid scalp contact if concerned.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Pregnant women shouldn't get vaccines.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Flu and Tdap vaccines are strongly recommended; only live vaccines (MMR, varicella) are contraindicated.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Stress will cause miscarriage.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Normal stress doesn't cause miscarriage though extreme trauma/chronic stress may slightly increase risks.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can predict labor by how the baby is carrying.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Fetal position doesn't reliably predict labor onset; even engaged babies may not come for weeks.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Ultrasounds can harm the baby.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Diagnostic ultrasounds use non-ionizing radiation with no proven harmful effects at clinical intensities.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You shouldn't exercise in the third trimester.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Regular exercise can continue until delivery if comfortable, though intensity may need adjustment.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Pregnant women shouldn't sleep on their back.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While left-side sleeping is ideal, occasional back sleeping is fine until it becomes uncomfortable.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't have dental work done.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dental cleanings and necessary procedures are safe; local anesthetics without epinephrine are preferred.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of the American Dental Association

myths_vs_reality.myth: Heart rate predicts the baby's gender.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Fetal heart rate varies normally between 110-160bpm regardless of sex; no predictive value.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication is the only effective ADHD treatment.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Combined approaches (medication + behavioral therapy + accommodations) work best for most individuals.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Stimulant medications are addictive for children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Properly prescribed stimulants don't cause addiction in ADHD kids; they reduce later substance abuse risks by 50%.

myths_vs_reality.myth: ADHD medications stunt growth.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Some children experience temporary slowed growth (1-2cm) but typically catch up by adulthood.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication changes personality.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Effective medication helps regulate attention/impulses without altering core personality traits.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You should take drug holidays on weekends.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Consistent medication often helps with non-academic functioning (social skills, family interactions).

myths_vs_reality.myth: Alternative diets (sugar-free, Feingold) cure ADHD.
myths_vs_reality.reality: No diet eliminates ADHD though some children may have individual food sensitivities affecting behavior.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Neurofeedback is a proven standalone treatment.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While promising, neurofeedback isn't FDA-approved as primary treatment and requires more research.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication doses should be based on weight alone.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Metabolism and brain chemistry vary widely; optimal dosing requires careful individual titration.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Adults respond to the same treatments as children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Adults often need different medication formulations/doses and coping strategies for workplace challenges.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Once you find an effective medication, you're set for life.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Needs change with development, hormones, and life circumstances requiring periodic reassessment.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Behavioral therapy doesn't work for ADHD.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Behavioral interventions are evidence-based, especially when combined with medication for children <6.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication fixes everything - no other supports needed.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Most individuals still benefit from organizational strategies, accommodations, and skill-building.

myths_vs_reality.myth: If one stimulant doesn't work, none will.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Response varies by formulation (methylphenidate vs amphetamine) and delivery system (XR, LA, patch).

myths_vs_reality.myth: Non-stimulants are always safer than stimulants.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Each medication class has different risk profiles; safety depends on individual health factors.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Adults can't start ADHD medication if not treated as kids.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Adults can begin treatment at any age if diagnosed; many weren't identified in childhood.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication loses effectiveness over time.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Tolerance is rare when properly dosed; perceived loss of effect often reflects new developmental demands.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Video games improve attention so they're good for ADHD.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While games capture attention, they don't generalize to real-world focus and may exacerbate dysregulation.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Omega-3 supplements replace medication.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Omega-3s may provide modest support but aren't comparable to first-line treatments for core symptoms.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics

myths_vs_reality.myth: All ADHD medications cause weight loss.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While decreased appetite is common initially, effects often stabilize; some non-stimulants may cause weight gain.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't take ADHD meds with antidepressants.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many combinations are safe and common; careful monitoring helps manage potential interactions.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Colored overlays or lenses cure dyslexia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While some find overlays helpful for reading comfort, they don't address phonological processing deficits.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics just need to read more to improve.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Structured, explicit phonics instruction is required - not just increased reading time.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Brain training games can rewire the dyslexic brain.
myths_vs_reality.reality: No evidence shows commercial brain games significantly improve reading; targeted literacy interventions do.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexia interventions only work for young children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Older students and adults can make significant gains with appropriate instruction.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All reading programs help dyslexia equally.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Only systematic, multisensory structured language programs (Orton-Gillingham, Wilson) are evidence-based.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Audio books are a crutch that prevent learning to read.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Audio books provide access to content while reading skills develop, supporting vocabulary and knowledge.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics should always sound out words.
myths_vs_reality.reality: A balanced approach (phonics + sight words + context) is most effective after basic decoding is mastered.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Spelling doesn't matter with spellcheck available.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Understanding spelling patterns improves reading fluency and written expression quality.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Cursive writing is easier for dyslexics.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Some find cursive helpful, others don't; individual preference should guide writing instruction.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics can't learn foreign languages.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While challenging, dyslexics can succeed with immersive, multisensory language instruction.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Extra time accommodations give unfair advantages.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Extra time simply allows dyslexics to demonstrate their knowledge without being hindered by slow decoding.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexia only affects reading, not math.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many dyslexics struggle with math word problems and memorizing math facts due to language aspects.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Vision therapy can correct dyslexia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Dyslexia is a language-processing issue, not a vision problem; vision therapy doesn't address core deficits.
myths_vs_reality.source: AAP Joint Statement on Vision Therapy

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics should avoid writing assignments.
myths_vs_reality.reality: With appropriate supports (graphic organizers, assistive tech), writing is an essential skill to develop.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Typing eliminates handwriting difficulties.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While helpful, keyboarding requires explicit instruction; handwriting remains important for quick notes.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics can't be good at standardized tests.
myths_vs_reality.reality: With proper accommodations and preparation, many dyslexics excel on standardized assessments.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Interventions should focus only on reading.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Comprehensive approaches address reading, writing, spelling, and self-advocacy skills.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyslexics outgrow their difficulties.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While skills improve with intervention, dyslexia is lifelong; for dyslexia is lifelong; adults need strategies for work environments.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All dyslexics benefit from the same font.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While some prefer OpenDyslexic font, individual preferences vary; no font works for everyone.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Early intervention guarantees grade-level reading.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While early help is crucial, progress depends on severity, intervention quality, and individual factors.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only mothers get depressed about child's learning struggles.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Fathers experience comparable rates of depression but are less likely to report or seek help.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Feeling depressed means you're a bad parent.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Depression is an illness, not a moral failing; good parents can struggle with mental health.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Antidepressants will make you numb to your child's needs.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Properly managed medications typically improve responsiveness by alleviating depressive symptoms.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Therapy is selfish when you should focus on your child.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Parental mental health treatment directly benefits child outcomes and family functioning.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You should hide your sadness from your child.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Modeling healthy emotional expression (within reason) teaches coping skills.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental depression doesn't affect children's learning.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Maternal depression is linked to poorer academic outcomes independent of child's learning disorder.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Support groups are just for complaining.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Evidence shows support groups reduce isolation and provide practical coping strategies.

myths_vs_reality.myth: If you're functional at work, you can't be that depressed.
myths_vs_reality.reality: High-functioning depression is common among parents who prioritize children's needs over their own.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Marital problems cause all parental depression.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While stress affects relationships, depression has biological components and multiple causes.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You don't need help if you're not suicidal.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Early intervention for mild-moderate depression prevents worsening and improves family outcomes.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Exercise and diet alone can cure parental depression.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While lifestyle helps, clinical depression often requires professional treatment.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental depression lasts only until the child improves.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Without treatment, depression can persist even as child makes progress.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication means you're too weak to handle parenting.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Taking medication for depression is no different than treating diabetes or high blood pressure.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only young parents get depressed about diagnoses.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Parents of all ages experience grief/anger about child's challenges regardless of their age.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Siblings don't notice parental depression.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Children are highly attuned to parental moods even when adults try to hide symptoms.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Child and Family Studies

myths_vs_reality.myth: Religious faith should prevent parental depression.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While faith can be a coping resource, it doesn't make people immune to biological depression.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents who sought the diagnosis can't be depressed about it.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Even parents who advocated for assessment experience grief about the confirmed diagnosis.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental depression looks like constant sadness.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It often manifests as irritability, exhaustion, or emotional numbness rather than overt sadness.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of the American Academy of Child Psychiatry

myths_vs_reality.myth: You should be over the grief about the diagnosis within a year.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Grief resurfaces at developmental transitions (new schools, milestones peers reach); this is normal.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Happy moments mean the depression is gone.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Depression often involves capacity for joy amid persistent low mood or fatigue.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You need to drink milk daily for baby's bones.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Calcium can come from various sources (leafy greens, fortified foods); milk isn't essential if you're lactose intolerant.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Avoid all spicy food during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Spicy foods are safe unless they cause individual discomfort; they don't induce labor.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Prenatal vitamins replace the need for healthy eating.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Vitamins supplement but don't replace the benefits of whole foods and balanced nutrition.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Eating peanuts causes peanut allergies in baby.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Unless you're allergic, eating peanuts during pregnancy may reduce baby's allergy risk.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology

myths_vs_reality.myth: Vegetarian diets can't support healthy pregnancies.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Well-planned vegetarian/vegan diets are safe with attention to protein, iron, B12, and DHA.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Avoid all sushi during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Cooked sushi and reputable-source raw fish (low mercury) are generally safe in moderation.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You must eat organic to have a healthy baby.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Conventional produce is safe when properly washed; what matters most is eating varied fruits/vegetables.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Avoid eggs due to salmonella risk.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Pasteurized eggs and fully cooked eggs are safe and excellent protein sources.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Herbal teas are always safe alternatives to coffee.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Some herbal teas (black cohosh, pennyroyal) are unsafe; stick to pregnancy-safe varieties like ginger or peppermint.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You shouldn't gain weight in the first trimester.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While some lose weight from nausea, 1-5lb gain is normal; underweight women may need more.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Artificial sweeteners cause birth defects.
myths_vs_reality.reality: FDA-approved sweeteners (aspartame, sucralose) are safe in moderation except saccharin.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Eating liver provides iron for pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Liver's high vitamin A content makes it risky; choose other iron sources like lentils and lean meats.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You must force yourself to eat when nauseous.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Small, frequent bland snacks are better than forcing large meals when experiencing morning sickness.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Avoid all soft cheeses.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Pasteurized soft cheeses (most US products) are safe; only unpasteurized varieties carry listeria risk.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Pregnancy cravings indicate nutritional deficiencies.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Cravings are more likely hormonal; unusual cravings (pica) should be discussed with a doctor.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You can't eat any deli meats.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Heating deli meats until steaming kills listeria bacteria, making them safe to eat.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Avoid soy products during pregnancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Moderate soy consumption is safe and provides quality plant-based protein.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Salty foods cause preeclampsia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Salt restriction doesn't prevent preeclampsia; adequate intake is important for blood volume expansion.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All raw vegetables are unsafe.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Properly washed raw veggies are safe and provide important nutrients; avoid only pre-cut varieties with higher contamination risk.

myths_vs_reality.myth: You must drink 8 glasses of water daily.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Hydration needs vary; pale urine and thirst are better indicators than fixed amounts.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Vaccines cause autism.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Extensive research shows no link between vaccines and autism; the original study claiming this was fraudulent.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All autistic people have savant skills.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Only about 10% of autistic individuals show savant abilities; most have typical skill ranges.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism can be outgrown.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Autism is lifelong though symptoms may change with development and intervention.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Poor parenting causes autism.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Autism is a neurodevelopmental disorder with strong genetic/biological origins.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autistic people lack empathy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many autistic individuals experience deep empathy but may express it differently.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All autistic people are nonverbal.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Verbal abilities vary widely; many autistic individuals are highly verbal.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Speech and Hearing Research

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism only affects boys.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Girls are underdiagnosed but autism occurs in all genders at an estimated 3:1 male-to-female ratio.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autistic people don't want friends.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many desire social connections but struggle with conventional social norms.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Gluten-free diets cure autism.
myths_vs_reality.reality: No evidence supports GF diets as autism treatment unless celiac disease is present.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders

myths_vs_reality.myth: All autistic individuals have intellectual disability.
myths_vs_reality.reality: IQ ranges widely; many have average or above-average intelligence.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism is caused by screen time.
myths_vs_reality.reality: No credible evidence links screen exposure to autism development.

myths_vs_reality.myth: ABA therapy is the only effective treatment.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While ABA helps some, other approaches (speech therapy, OT, social skills training) are also evidence-based.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autistic people can't work regular jobs.
myths_vs_reality.reality: With appropriate supports, many autistic adults are successful in diverse careers.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism rates are increasing due to environmental toxins.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Increased diagnoses reflect broader criteria and better awareness, not necessarily more cases.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All autistic children have meltdowns.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Behavioral challenges vary; many develop coping strategies with support.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism can be diagnosed with a blood test.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Diagnosis relies on behavioral observation; no medical test exists yet.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autistic people don't understand humor.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many enjoy and create humor, though preferences may differ from neurotypical peers.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism is a mental illness.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Autism is a neurological difference, not a mental health disorder.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All autistic individuals need the same supports.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Needs vary widely - 'If you've met one person with autism, you've met one person with autism.'

myths_vs_reality.myth: Autism is a modern condition.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Historical accounts describe individuals with autistic traits long before the diagnosis existed.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculia just means being bad at math.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It's a specific learning disability affecting number sense and quantitative reasoning.

myths_vs_reality.myth: People with dyscalculia can't do any math.
myths_vs_reality.reality: With strategies and accommodations, many develop functional math skills.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculia is rare.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It affects 3-7% of the population, similar to dyslexia prevalence.

myths_vs_reality.myth: It only affects school math.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Impacts daily life (telling time, handling money, measuring quantities).

myths_vs_reality.myth: More drill/practice will fix it.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Requires specialized instruction focusing on conceptual understanding.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculics can't have strong visual-spatial skills.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many excel in visual arts/design despite number difficulties.

myths_vs_reality.myth: It's caused by math anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Anxiety is a result, not the cause, of the neurological difference.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only children have dyscalculia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It persists into adulthood though coping strategies improve.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Calculators solve all problems.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Conceptual understanding is still needed to set up problems correctly.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculia means low IQ.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It can occur across the full IQ range.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All math struggles indicate dyscalculia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Diagnosis requires specific cognitive deficits, not just poor performance.

myths_vs_reality.myth: It only affects arithmetic.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Also impacts understanding time, directions, sequences, and patterns.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculics can't manage money.
myths_vs_reality.reality: With tools and systems, many develop financial competence.

myths_vs_reality.myth: It's the same as math dyslexia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While related, dyscalculia specifically affects number sense, not just symbols.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculia can't be diagnosed until school age.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Early signs (counting difficulties, quantity comparison) may appear by age 4.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All dyslexics have dyscalculia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While co-occurrence is common (30-60%), they're distinct conditions.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculics can't be good at science.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many excel in qualitative sciences (biology, geology) despite math challenges.

myths_vs_reality.myth: It's untreatable.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Early intervention can significantly improve number sense and math skills.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Dyscalculia is just a memory problem.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Involves core deficits in quantity representation and numerical processing.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only boys have dyscalculia.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Affects both genders equally though boys are more often identified.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Worrying means you care more as a parent.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Excessive worry impairs parenting effectiveness; calm presence is more beneficial.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Child and Family Studies

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety is always about the child's safety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Often includes social judgment fears ('What will others think of my parenting?').

myths_vs_reality.myth: Anxious parents always raise anxious children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While risk increases, children can develop resilience with proper support.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only first-time parents experience significant anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Each child's unique needs can trigger new anxieties regardless of parenting experience.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety will go away once the child reaches certain milestones.
myths_vs_reality.reality: New developmental stages often bring new worries; coping skills are lifelong needs.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Anxiety makes parents more vigilant about real dangers.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Anxiety often focuses on unlikely risks while overlooking more probable concerns.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents should never show anxiety in front of children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Modeling healthy coping with anxiety ('I feel nervous but I can handle this') teaches resilience.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety is always irrational.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Some anxiety is proportionate (e.g., legitimate medical concerns); the issue is when it becomes impairing.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only mothers experience parenting anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Fathers experience comparable rates but are less likely to acknowledge or seek help.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Anxious parents should avoid discussing their worries.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Processing concerns with supportive adults (not children) often reduces anxiety.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parenting gets less anxiety-provoking as children get older.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While physical safety worries may decrease, social/emotional concerns often increase.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety is always bad for children.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Mild anxiety can motivate protective behaviors; only excessive anxiety causes harm.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parents of special needs children should expect constant anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While stress is higher, many develop resilience and find joy in their parenting journey.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Autism and Developmental Disorders

myths_vs_reality.myth: Anxiety means you're not cut out for parenting.
myths_vs_reality.reality: All parents experience some anxiety; it's how you manage it that matters.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety is always obvious.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many high-functioning parents hide anxiety through perfectionism or over-preparation.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parenting classes will eliminate anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While helpful, clinical anxiety often requires targeted treatment beyond general education.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Anxious parents can't set boundaries well.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Many anxious parents actually over-control; the challenge is finding balanced discipline.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety peaks during infancy.
myths_vs_reality.reality: For many, anxiety increases as children gain independence in school-age years.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Medication is the only treatment for parental anxiety.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Cognitive-behavioral therapy and mindfulness are also evidence-based treatments.
myths_vs_reality.source: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology

myths_vs_reality.myth: Parental anxiety means you love your child more.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Love isn't measured by worry; secure attachment comes from consistent care, not anxious vigilance.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations give unfair advantages.
myths_vs_reality.reality: They level the playing field by removing disability-related barriers.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Extra time means unlimited time.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Standard is 50-100% additional time based on documented needs.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations make students dependent.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Properly implemented, they foster independence by allowing demonstration of true capabilities.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Only severe disabilities qualify.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Even mild impairments may warrant accommodations if they substantially limit functioning.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Private schools don't have to provide accommodations.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Those receiving federal funds must comply with Section 504 protections.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations are only for academics.
myths_vs_reality.reality: May include non-academic areas like lunch, recess, transportation, and extracurriculars.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Once granted, accommodations never change.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Should be reviewed annually as needs evolve with development.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Teachers can refuse accommodations they disagree with.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Legally mandated accommodations aren't optional for educators.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations lower academic standards.
myths_vs_reality.reality: They maintain standards while changing how information is accessed/demonstrated.

myths_vs_reality.myth: All students with the same diagnosis need the same accommodations.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Must be individualized based on specific functional limitations.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations are only for elementary school.
myths_vs_reality.reality: College and workplace accommodations continue protections into adulthood.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Speech-to-text is cheating for writing assignments.
myths_vs_reality.reality: It's an accommodation for students whose ideas outpace handwriting/typing abilities.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Quiet rooms are unnecessary privileges.
myths_vs_reality.reality: For sensory-sensitive students, they're essential for equal assessment access.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations are only for cognitive disabilities.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Also cover physical, sensory, mental health, and chronic health conditions.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Extended deadlines mean no deadlines.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Structured flexibility (e.g., 2 extra days per assignment) maintains accountability.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations are expensive for schools.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Most (extended time, preferential seating, note-taking) require minimal resources.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Gifted students don't need accommodations.
myths_vs_reality.reality: Twice-exceptional (2e) students need both enrichment and disability supports.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Peer helpers replace professional supports.
myths_vs_reality.reality: While beneficial, peers can't substitute for trained specialists' services.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations must be written in an IEP.
myths_vs_reality.reality: 504 Plans also provide legally binding accommodations without special education services.

myths_vs_reality.myth: Accommodations guarantee academic success.
myths_vs_reality.reality: They remove barriers but don't eliminate need for effort and appropriate instruction.
